citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the program of veterinary care, the environment enhancement plan for nonhuman primates, the
contingency plan, and the acquisition records were not available for review by the inspector.
Review of records required by the Animal Welfare Act facilitates the inspection process by allowing the inspector to
determine compliance and evaluate animal welfare. The facility shall ensure that the records required to be kept by the
Animal Welfare Act and the regulations are complete and available for USDA APHIS officials to examine.

In the kitchen, there is spoiled produce being stored in the refrigerators and on the counters which is causing the room to
have an unpleasant odor. Inside the refrigerators, there is a head of lettuce with diffuse black discoloration, strawberries
covered in a fuzzy growth, and bananas that have darkly discolored peels that are starting to leak fluid. On the counters,
there are packages of corn on the cob with fuzzy growth and discoloration, shriveled onions, and a box of unrefrigerated
produce covered in small ants. There is no separation between what is to be fed to the gibbons and what is for disposal.
Additionally, there is a container of poison rat bait being stored on top of the refrigerator and pieces of chewed bait could
be seen on top of the counter where food is stored.
Spoiled perishable items can further compromise other supplies of food stored in close proximity to them or attract
unwanted pests as they continue to degrade. Ingestion of contaminated feed can cause illness in the animals. Storing
toxic substances in food storage areas can cause illness and harm to animals. Supplies of food and bedding must be
stored in a manner that protects the supplies from spoilage, contamination, and vermin infestation. The supplies must be
stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow cleaning underneath and around the supplies. Food requiring
refrigeration must be stored accordingly, and all food must be stored a manner that prevents contamination and
deterioration of its nutritive value. Substances that are toxic to the nonhuman primates but that are required for normal
husbandry practices must not be stored in food storage and preparation areas, but may be stored in cabinets in the
animal areas.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
In the kitchen, there is an excessive amount of rodent feces on the floor and in empty boxes around the room. There are
also piles of insulation debris in areas where rodents have chewed through the wall. There is evidence of attempts to
control the rodent issue, including poison bait seen in the kitchen.
Pests such as rats can spread disease and contaminate food, surfaces, and animal housing areas. An effective program
for control of insects, external parasites affecting nonhuman primates, and birds and mammals that are pests, must be
established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination by pests
in animal areas.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 10/12/2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.126(a)(2) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
At the time of inspection, the program of veterinary care, the environment enhancement plan for nonhuman primates, the 
contingency plan, and the acquisition records were not available for review by the inspector. 
Review of records required by the Animal Welfare Act facilitates the inspection process by allowing the inspector to 
determine compliance and evaluate animal welfare. The facility shall ensure that the records required to be kept by the 
Animal Welfare Act and the regulations are complete and available for USDA APHIS officials to examine. 
3.75(e) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
In the kitchen, there is spoiled produce being stored in the refrigerators and on the counters which is causing the room to 
have an unpleasant odor. Inside the refrigerators, there is a head of lettuce with diffuse black discoloration, strawberries 
covered in a fuzzy growth, and bananas that have darkly discolored peels that are starting to leak fluid. On the counters, 
there are packages of corn on the cob with fuzzy growth and discoloration, shriveled onions, and a box of unrefrigerated 
produce covered in small ants. There is no separation between what is to be fed to the gibbons and what is for disposal.  
Additionally, there is a container of poison rat bait being stored on top of the refrigerator and pieces of chewed bait could 
be seen on top of the counter where food is stored.  
Spoiled perishable items can further compromise other supplies of food stored in close proximity to them or attract 
unwanted pests as they continue to degrade. Ingestion of contaminated feed can cause illness in the animals. Storing 
toxic substances in food storage areas can cause illness and harm to animals. Supplies of food and bedding must be 
stored in a manner that protects the supplies from spoilage, contamination, and vermin infestation. The supplies must be 
stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow cleaning underneath and around the supplies. Food requiring 
refrigeration must be stored accordingly, and all food must be stored a manner that prevents contamination and 
deterioration of its nutritive value. Substances that are toxic to the nonhuman primates but that are required for normal 
husbandry practices must not be stored in food storage and preparation areas, but may be stored in cabinets in the 
animal areas. 
3.84(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.

In the kitchen, there is an excessive amount of rodent feces on the floor and in empty boxes around the room. There are 
also piles of insulation debris in areas where rodents have chewed through the wall. There is evidence of attempts to 
control the rodent issue, including poison bait seen in the kitchen. 
Pests such as rats can spread disease and contaminate food, surfaces, and animal housing areas. An effective program 
for control of insects, external parasites affecting nonhuman primates, and birds and mammals that are pests, must be 
established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination by pests 
in animal areas. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 10/12/2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and 
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
